0402c473-cf21-46bf-bfa5-858536cdbcf2.description: Mandate installation of point-source carbon capture and sequestration (CSS) on all fossil-fuel using facilities to store CO2 underground.
0402c473-cf21-46bf-bfa5-858536cdbcf2.name: Carbon Capture and Sequestration
0402c473-cf21-46bf-bfa5-858536cdbcf2.notes:
SR: Open to less optimistic estimates, but from what I'm reading, existing point-source CCS technology can reduce life-cycle emissions of fossil fuel plants by 75-84%.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0301421507004120

However, we should also consider the increased energy cost. How can we incorporate this? 

"Postcombustion chemical absorption imposes an energy penalty of about 15% to
30% for natural gas plants and 30% to 60% for coal plants"

https://www.annualreviews.org/doi/pdf/10.1146/annurev.energy.29.082703.145619

Seems like in practice actual carbon emissions captured is much lower than the 80-90% that's usually set as a target (esp as mentioned above when you take into account increase energy and upstream emissions):
https://twitter.com/mzjacobson/status/1418244206628245506
https://news.stanford.edu/2019/10/25/study-casts-doubt-carbon-capture/
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2021/jul/20/a-shocking-failure-chevron-criticised-for-missing-carbon-capture-target-at-wa-gas-project
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-energy-carbon-capture/problems-plagued-u-s-co2-capture-project-before-shutdown-document-idUSKCN2523K8
https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatchewan/sask-carbon-capture-short-of-target-ceo-says-1.5126409
https://www.carbonbrief.org/around-the-world-in-22-carbon-capture-projects
https://www.vice.com/en/article/g5q573/the-worlds-only-coal-carbon-capture-plant-is-regularly-breaking

Ballpark from these links suggests in practice CCS captures 10-30% of emissions

The CO2 captured here usually goes towards EOR so we can add that as another effect: https://www.vox.com/energy-and-environment/2019/10/2/20838646/climate-change-carbon-capture-enhanced-oil-recovery-eor

Or just assume that it won't be used in that way

From the book regarding species: 
the lifeblood of a healthy ecosystem are the large non-ruminant herbivores, such as the white rhinoceros,
wildebeest, Bactrian camel, Przewalski’s horse, African wild ass and kulan.362 The latter group
also produce much less methane than domesticated ruminants.363 The restoration of large
frugivores (fruit-eating animals) such as tapirs and Asian forest elephants, could increase the
carbon sequestration capacity of tropical forests by 10%.364 Predators matter too. If Canada’s
wolves return to their former glory, their predation of moose would create a healthier boreal
forest that could potentially cancel out nearly all of Canada’s carbon emissions.365

https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/10.1098/rstb.2017.0432
Large herbivores can interact with climate change in a number of direct and indirect ways [40,41]. In the Arctic, caribou or reindeer (Rangifer tarandus) and muskoxen (Ovibos moschatus) are the only large herbivores. With rising temperature, thermophilic plant species are invading the tundra and these are preferred by the herbivores. Therefore, reindeer and muskoxen are able to maintain the present vegetation composition even in a warmer climate [42]. Furthermore, they prevent woody plant encroachment with increasing temperatures, which in turn leads to a higher albedo [43], with a cooling effect. Large herbivores may increase soil carbon sequestration, when they consolidate the persistence of the permafrost 

https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1029/2008GL036332

0631b696-1e92-451b-a202-a803f4da0067.name: Ash Dieback
0631b696-1e92-451b-a202-a803f4da0067.notes:
a chronic fungal disease of ash trees in Europe
Ash dieback (Hymenoscyphus fraxineus) is a fungus which originated in Asia. It doesn’t cause much damage on its native hosts of the Manchurian ash (Fraxinus mandshurica) and the Chinese ash (Fraxinus chinensis) in its native range. However, its introduction to Europe about 30 years ago has devastated the European ash (Fraxinus excelsior) because our native ash species did not evolve with the fungus and this means it has no natural defence against it.

Per the book, assume land use of 10W/m2 (per year) so about 0.0114m3/kWh.

The book assumes 0 emissions for solar but we can use this figure from https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy13osti/56487.pdf, of ~40g CO2eq/kWh

Mekonnen, M. M., Gerbens-Leenes, P. W., & Hoekstra, A. Y. (2015). The consumptive water footprint of electricity and heat: a global assessment. Environmental Science: Water Research & Technology, 1(3), 285-297.
https://waterfootprint.org/media/downloads/Mekonnen-et-al-2015_1.pdf
For PV has a range of 6.4-303 m3 per TJ of net energy produced, so let's say 154.7 m3/TJ, which is about 0.557L/kWh.

For energy inputs, https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421513003856 gives a range of 6-12 for PV, that range is from 2009 and presumably solar PV production has improved a lot since then, so maybe say the higher end of that range (12). Which means about 0.083kWh/kWh

For biodiversity pressure, assume it's all through land use.

For feedstock, we assume that it's all captured through land use (of course would vary according to sun/sky conditions/solar irradiance but I believe that land use number encapsulates an average of those)

1af360c3-5f08-4fae-9ea1-8264d4c1fc5a.description: Produced by nuclear fission of uranium and plutonium in power plants.
1af360c3-5f08-4fae-9ea1-8264d4c1fc5a.name: Nuclear Power
1af360c3-5f08-4fae-9ea1-8264d4c1fc5a.notes:
Per this article from the Rocky Mountain Institute: https://rmi.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/2011-07_RenewableEnergysFootprintMyth.pdf, which cites https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1364032108001354 (V. Fthenakis & H.C. Kim, Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews 13:1465–1474 (2009)):

119 m2/GWh for nuclear (in the US) so 0.000119m2/kWh
I believe this accounts for extraction etc

https://css.umich.edu/factsheets/nuclear-energy-factsheet
> -  A uranium fuel pellet (~1/2 in. height and diameter) contains the energy equivalent of one ton of coal or 149 gallons of oil.10 Typical reactors hold 18 million pellets.6
> - Each kWh of nuclear electricity requires 0.1-0.3 kWh of life cycle energy inputs.20 [say 0.2 and split 50/50 between electricity and fuel]
> - The life cycle GHG intensity of nuclear power is estimated to be 34-60 gCO2e/kWh—far below baseload sources such as coal (1,001 gCO2e/kWh).21,22 [say 47gCO2e/kWh]
> - Nuclear power plants consume 270-670 gallons of water/MWh, depending on operating efficiency and site conditions.23 [say 470 gallons/MWh, or 2136.66L/MWh]

For energy inputs, this also gives a range of 5-15 EROI for nuclear, so 0.2 to 0.06kWh/kWh.

The CO2e estimate above is close to this:
"Emeritus Professor of Physics at Imperial College London Keith Barnham contends, “Far from coming in at six grams of CO2 per unit of electricity for Hinkley C,” the new reactor being built in the UK, “the true figure is probably well above 50 grams—breaching the [Committee on Climate Change’s] recommended limit for new sources of power generation beyond 2030.”" https://bostonreview.net/science-nature/samuel-miller-mcdonald-nuclear-power-our-best-bet-against-climate-change

another source for co2 intensity:
https://www.stormsmith.nl/Media/downloads/storm_van_leeuwen200607energy_from_uranium.pdf

https://whatisnuclear.com/energy-density.html
> A single fuel pellet may weigh about 10 grams so it contains 40,000 MJ in a typical reactor [LWR] and 800,000 MJ in a breeder reactor.
So about 10g/11111.111kWh = 0.0009g/kWh

"Another limitation of nuclear power is that it is not a long-term solution, in one crucial respect: it depends on fissile materials that are nonrenewable, namely uranium-233, uranium-235, and plutonium. At current rates of consumption, there may be between 130 and 230 years of recoverable uranium available globally. Derek Abbott, Professor of Electrical and Electronic Engineering at the University of Adelaide, has calculated that scaling nuclear production up to meet global demand could leave just five years of uranium supplies." https://bostonreview.net/science-nature/samuel-miller-mcdonald-nuclear-power-our-best-bet-against-climate-change

one planning cycle

Smallholders use 24% of ag land, produce 29% of crops (in kcals), some of which go into fuel and feed, and ultimately contribute to 32% of the food supply (directly consumed crops).

TV, similar numbers here: Ricciardi, Vincent, Navin Ramankutty, Zia Mehrabi, Larissa Jarvis, and Brenton Chookolingo. "How much of the world's food do smallholders produce?." Global food security 17 (2018): 64-72.

They tend to have higher yields (more labor intensive, less land intensive) and better biodiversity effects.

Nicholas suggests 40-50% max. Starting kcal demand is 6840000000000000, so that would be 2736000000000000.0-3420000000000000.0, let's do 3078000000000000.0 which is in the middle.

28a39677-163d-4a39-88ee-c6a842bec79c.description: Grow biofuels, burn them for energy, then capture and store the CO2 emitted.
28a39677-163d-4a39-88ee-c6a842bec79c.name: BECCS
28a39677-163d-4a39-88ee-c6a842bec79c.notes:
The 2.5% figure actually includes geothermal, tidal/wave, as well as biomass...others seem marginal enough that we can just assign it all to biomass.

The book has 0.3W/m2 for liquid biofuels (ethanol/biodiesel) and 0.9W/m2 for solid biofuels (wood) and gaseous biofuels (phytomass). We'll assume the latter for all biomass electricity, so that's 7.884kWh/m2 or 0.1268m2/kWh

https://waterfootprint.org/media/downloads/Mekonnen-et-al-2015_1.pdf gives a water footprint of 48,000-500,000 m3/TJ net energy for firewood; going to be very crude and assume that all BECCS are using wood pellets and that firewood is equivalent to that. So say 274,000 m3/TJ or 986.4L/kWh

this paper gives different numbers: https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.0812619106
> For electricity, sugar beet, maize, and sugar cane are the most favorable crops [50 m3/gigajoule (GJ)]. Rapeseed and jatropha, typical energy crops, are disadvantageous (400 m3/GJ). For ethanol, sugar beet, and potato (60 and 100 m3/GJ) are the most advantageous, followed by sugar cane (110 m3/GJ); sorghum (400 m3/GJ) is the most unfavorable. For biodiesel, soybean and rapeseed show to be the most favorable WF (400 m3/GJ); jatropha has an adverse WF (600 m3/GJ).
These are all way, way lower than the firewood estimate. For BECCS we'll use 50m3/GJ (0.18L/kWh); for biofuels we'll use 80m3/GJ (0.29L/kWh).

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421513003856 gives the following EROIs:
- Ethanol (sugarcane): 0.8 to 10
- Corn-based ethanol: 0.8 to 1.6
- Biodiesel: 1.3
Let's say 5.4, or 0.185kWh/kWh, split between electricity and fuel.

This plant in the UK is supposed to capture 350tCO2/year while generating 300MWh/year: https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/911268/potential-of-bioenergy-with-carbon-capture.pdf (from 1/2020) using 100% wood pellets (other figures I've found were for biomass/coal co-firing plants). This would be about 1166.67g CO2 sequestered/kWh

As for N2O emissions, assuming the biomass is grown similar to industrial agriculture, we have 0.0001473g N2O for our industrial ag crop process, and with the conversion of 860.421kcals/kWh we get about 0.12674g N2O/kWh from fertilizer application. The problem with this conversion is that with our industrial ag crop process we are only counting human-consumed kcals; in practice inedible parts of the plants are also burned for energy. So this figure is almost certainly an overestimate, maybe just hand wave and cut it into half to 0.06337gN2O/kWh.

31ac9a2e-af8c-4422-b2d1-bf86684aaee5.flavor:
After decades of business-as-usual, corporate and governmental promises of "net zero by 2050" have achieved next to nothing...if they were ever meaningful to begin with. The world is well into the most turbulent century in recorded history, and it is too late to undo its planetary disasters. But these disasters destroyed the foundations of the capitalist order; this greatest of crises resoundingly proved the need for a different way forward.

(SRM started 10 years ago)

387ed612-9b7a-4c81-82db-8a8697172667.description: Install DAC units to take CO2 out of the atmosphere.
387ed612-9b7a-4c81-82db-8a8697172667.name: Direct Air Capture
387ed612-9b7a-4c81-82db-8a8697172667.notes:
to sequester 30 gt C a year by 2100, DACCS would require massive amount of energy, up to 300 EJ. total world energy production in 2020 was 550 EJ. Study includes charts comparing water, land, and energy use by DACCS, BECCS, and afforestation. authors expect it to be scaled up 1.5gt C per year

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-019-10842-5

From that paper:
For 30 GtCO2/year it requires something like 250EJ/yr, about 500Gt H2O/yr = 500km3/yr, and negligible land use. So every 1.5GtCO2/year requires 12.5EJ/yr (~3.47e12 kWh/year, rounded to 3.5e12kWh/year) and 25km3 water/yr
So if it can scale up 1.5GtCO2/year we can make this a 5-year project with upgrades.

Uses.
http://www.infinitreellc.com/

3fe30749-664d-4a81-9e01-e249d63ff8f9.description: Illuminate cities using satellites that will reflect sunlight onto nighttime cities below. This project will marginally lower electrical demand and will adversely affect nocturnal animals.
3fe30749-664d-4a81-9e01-e249d63ff8f9.name: Artificial Moons
3fe30749-664d-4a81-9e01-e249d63ff8f9.notes:
--we'll have to guess what the electricity savings will be for this project. I just threw in a biodiversity cost. TV
--lighting is about 15-19% of electricity production globally, so I reduced this by 10%. 
--see Bachanek, Konrad Henryk, Blanka Tundys, Tomasz Wiśniewski, Ewa Puzio, and Anna Maroušková. "Intelligent Street Lighting in a Smart City Concepts—A Direction to Energy Saving in Cities: An Overview and Case Study." Energies 14, no. 11 (2021): 3018.

The plan behind the artificial moon
As one would imagine, this has been a very ambitious undertaking for the company.  According to information shared in the local periodical The People's Daily, the moon, which would generate a "dusk-like glow", could light an area that covers a diameter ranging from 10-80 km (no doubt while reading this, some of our IE readerships has already begun picturing images of the Batman logo and the residents of Gotham City). 

What's more, the proposed second moon would shine 8 times brighter than the real moon, and most importantly from a logistical perspective, could be controlled within a significant range of at least a few dozen meters.  Part science, part stranger than fiction, the satellite offers promising possibilities, with Wu pointing to the original inspiration behind the glowing orb in the sky by referring to "a French artist, who imagined hanging a necklace made of mirrors above the Earth which could reflect sunshine through the streets of Paris all year round".

outcomes.text: Some say the dusk-like glow from the 2nd moon is romantic.

0.text: Aquatic species, particularly fish, are vulnerable to the impacts of dams. The dam constructed on the border between Paraguay and Brazil in the 1970s and 1980s, resulted in a 70 percent loss of biodiversity.

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: The dams have just contributed to climate change. As reservoirs fill, upstream forests are flooded, eliminating their function as carbon sinks. As the drowned vegetation decomposes, decaying plants in manmade reservoirs release methane, a powerful greenhouse gas.

c3ef42a5-f3a1-40c3-9337-8361b8fa1cc3.text: That makes reservoirs sources of emissions — particularly those in tropical forests, where there is dense growth. It’s estimated that greenhouse gas emissions from dams amount to about a billion tons annually, making it a significant global source.

Once-in-a-decade heatwave:
+1.0C: happens 2.8x as frequently; +1.2C hotter
+1.5C: happens 4.1x as frequently; +1.9C hotter
+2.0C: happens 5.6x as frequently; +2.6C hotter
+4.0C: happens 9.4x as frequently, +5.1C hotter

"Beyond 1.5C, the heat in tropical regions of the world will push societies to the limits, with stifling humidity preventing sweat from evaporating and making it difficult for people to cool down. Extreme heatwaves could make parts of the Middle East too hot for humans to endure, scientists have found, with rising temperatures also posing enormous risks for China and India." 

"A severe heatwave historically expected once a decade will happen every other year at 2C."

4e3ac93f-1207-488d-8dff-8ad8fd2226d2.description: Cells are harvested from animals, cultured to multiply to create muscle tissue.
4e3ac93f-1207-488d-8dff-8ad8fd2226d2.name: Cellular Meat
4e3ac93f-1207-488d-8dff-8ad8fd2226d2.notes:
LC: https://gfi.org/science/the-science-of-cultivated-meat/
Crossover with organ growing tech. 

takes significant scientific capital

seems like lab-meat ain't coming any time soon:

https://thecounter.org/lab-grown-cultivated-meat-cost-at-scale/

A friend of mine who work on the topic (Jan Dutkiewicz) says that lab meat might be possible at scale by 2040 or 2050, but that's a big if

makes vegan or vegetarian mandate easier

Probably too little too late

Maybe it will cut into meat consumption by 20% or so, but will not replace meat unless there is a mandate

https://cedelft.eu/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2021/04/CE_Delft_190107_LCA_of_cultivated_meat_Def.pdf
Energy use: 147-264MJ/kg (~205.5MJ/kg = 57.1kWh/kg)
Land use: 1.8m2/kg
Water use: 42-56litre/kg (~49litre/kg)
> The main driver for the carbon footprint in the 
conventional energy scenario is electricity use during production, followed by the 
production of medium ingredients. A significant reduction in carbon footprint can be 
achieved by decarbonising the energy mix. In the (upstream) production of medium, 
reductions that can be achieved by decarbonisation are smaller because a part of the 
carbon footprint there is caused by the agricultural production of the feedstock and 
chemicals used during production of the medium ingredients, which rely on heavy industrial 
processes, that are harder to decarbonise. Scaffolds (assumed in this study to be in the 
form of a hydrogel), equipment, wastewater treatment and HVAC of the facility make up a 
relatively minor part of the carbon footprint (total of < 2%).
So aside from energy, the other main contributor to GHG emissions (more significant under the renewable scenario) is the medium's production: roughly 1.25kgCO2eq/kg
Conversion from kg to kcals:
Beef sausage is about ~3400kcals/kg (https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/746779/nutrients)
Pork sausage is about ~3200kcals/kg (https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/746780/nutrients)
Chicken is about ~1500kcals/kg (https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/331897/nutrients)
So say 2700kcals/kg on average

These figures then are:
Energy use: 57.1kWh/kg = 0.2kWh/kcal
Land use: 1.8m2/kg = 0.00067m2/kcal
Water use: 49litre/kg = 0.018litre/kcal
Non-energy GHG emissions: 1.25kgCO2eq/kg = 1250.0gCO2eq/kg = 0.463gCO2eq/kcal

4e3efe6b-0cce-46b3-9dde-05c252ddbdff.description: Follows the same process as grey, with the additional technologies necessary to capture the CO2 produced when hydrogen is split from methane (or from coal) and store it for long term.
4e3efe6b-0cce-46b3-9dde-05c252ddbdff.name: Blue Hydrogen
4e3efe6b-0cce-46b3-9dde-05c252ddbdff.notes:
Methane and carbon dioxide emissions (averaged b/w with and w/o flue): https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/ese3.956
Land: calculated using fuel requirements and methane fuel efficiency below
Water: pubs.acs.org/doi/full/10.1021/acsenergylett.1c01375
Fuel: sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0360319919300230
Electricity: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0306261920314136?via%3Dihub#s0105
(We'll use the same values for water to conduct hydrolysis.)
kWh/kg H2: https://hypertextbook.com/facts/2005/MichelleFung.shtml

Elsewhere I'm seeing EROI of 1:4 for grey/blue hydrogen (https://theconversation.com/blue-hydrogen-what-is-it-and-should-it-replace-natural-gas-166053), still not great, but 1:45 just seemed way too high -FT

4f3411f9-54f2-41ee-9e78-a14b392bb053.description: Increasing production yields for farmers using robots to reduce human labor for tasks like spraying and weeding, crop harvesting, seeding and planting, soil analysis, and livestock feeding.
4f3411f9-54f2-41ee-9e78-a14b392bb053.name: Agricultural Robotics
4f3411f9-54f2-41ee-9e78-a14b392bb053.notes:
Reduces labor required for agriculture, with minor penalty to yields, increased energy requirements, and harms biodiversity

On the fence about this one--from what I understand, agricultural robotics are still really bad compared to human labor...changed a few things to reflect that. - FT

5703ffc0-57d6-4253-8491-2d2b602bcdd3.description: Dump iron into the oceans to stimulate diatom growth, which might sequester four gigatonnes of CO2 a year. This technique might not work and could have detrimental ecological effects.
5703ffc0-57d6-4253-8491-2d2b602bcdd3.flavor: “Give me a half tanker of iron, and I will give you an ice age.” John Martin, 1988
5703ffc0-57d6-4253-8491-2d2b602bcdd3.name: Ocean Iron Fertilization
5703ffc0-57d6-4253-8491-2d2b602bcdd3.notes:
The idea here is that perhaps if we reduce fishing pressure on the oceans (AnimalCalories<10%), marine ecosystems could have the functionality to pull carbon into the deep. However, there's a chance the project could backfire, successfully sequestering carbon, but creating anoxic dead zones on the seafloor.

https://www.whoi.edu/oceanus/feature/fertilizing-the-ocean-with-iron/

TV, I might revise this--who made this one?

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: The experiment succeeded in drawing down carbon from the atmosphere, but it had an uninteded side-effect...

6c0852f2-5432-4ad2-876b-aa73a6a2d931.speaker: The Climatologist
6c0852f2-5432-4ad2-876b-aa73a6a2d931.text: The rotting algae formed anoxic dead zones on the abyssal plains, killing much ocean life...

outcomes.text: The experiment succeeded in drawing down carbon from the atmosphere, but it had an uninteded side-effect: the decomposition of plankton formed anoxic dead zones on the abyssal plains.

0.speaker: The Ecologist
0.text: The abundance of diatoms not only sequestered carbon, but fed millions of salmon fry and other marine life. This was a great success!

outcomes.text: The new abundance of phytoplankton catalyzed a resurgence of whale populations, who helped to sequester carbon from the surface down to the seafloor sediments.

0.speaker: The Engineer

outcomes.text: For a short time, the surface waters bloomed, but there was no mechanism to transport it to the deep...

58acdfec-01b9-49c2-986f-c8d5e11a4bda.notes:
Emissions decrease derived from estimate of militaries accounting for 6% global emissions:
https://www.sgr.org.uk/resources/carbon-boot-print-military-0

I also added a multiplier to make iron and steel 10% less electric-intensive based on the idea that we could salvage metal from military infrastructure. Couldn't find a source for this, but thought it might be cool to add a side-effect.

Changes the iron and steel effect to affect metal shortage events instead, bit easier that way - FT

5c67f0aa-5f1b-4139-bab0-b18ebd793761.description: The good life isn't about having more things. Degrowth reduces energy and material consumption in the Global North while funding social programs to provide material  support for everyone.

630eaa03-40a1-4332-9c5c-759d8bfe97ad.description: Install co-generation systems in eligible structures and power facilities to generate electricity and heat at the same time, making use of otherwise wasted heat.
630eaa03-40a1-4332-9c5c-759d8bfe97ad.name: Co-Generation
630eaa03-40a1-4332-9c5c-759d8bfe97ad.notes:
Easier if denser cities have also been planned (e.g. banning cars)

Not sure how much it would reduce energy costs for buildings, but a significant amount. Probably this and passive buildings get your energy use down to zero

A simple but effective technology widely used in the USSR and Scandinavia, but failed in the US because it provided unwelcome competition to energy utilities.

https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/how-does-cogeneration-provide-heat-power/ "Cogeneration power plants often operate at 50 to 70 percent higher efficiency rates than single-generation facilities."

Effect values: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/engineering/cogeneration
"Along with the saving of fossil fuels, cogeneration also allows to reduce the emission of greenhouse gases (particularly CO2 emission). The production of electricity being on-site, the burden on the utility network is reduced and the transmission line losses eliminated."

69654c23-965e-40b3-bd05-3cd32550a871.description: A controversial technology among ecologists. While attempts to bring back mammoths are likely more crowd pleasers than real science, recently extinct animals might be usefully restored.
69654c23-965e-40b3-bd05-3cd32550a871.flavor: The Iberian ibex is the only species to go extinct twice: in 2000 when the last animal died and in 2003 when a cloned ibex died shortly after birth.
69654c23-965e-40b3-bd05-3cd32550a871.name: De-Extinction Research
69654c23-965e-40b3-bd05-3cd32550a871.notes:
Passenger pigeon, woolly mammoth, Carolina parakeet, bucardo, auroch, gastric-brooding frog...

3 different outcomes (but none of them will change direction of the game):

Scientists clone extinct x, but it is born with a lung defect and dies ten minutes after birth.

Scientists clone large numbers of x, but within a year half of them have perished from hunger or predation, and the outlook for the remaining population is grim.

Scientists have cloned a large number of x, and it seems likely that a viable population might be established if their nature preserve is protected from encroachment by poachers and loggers.

6b9390d3-90b5-425b-bc43-49475b9d3460.description: Inject particles into clouds to reflect more sunlight, reducing global temperatures.
6b9390d3-90b5-425b-bc43-49475b9d3460.name: Cloud Brightening
6b9390d3-90b5-425b-bc43-49475b9d3460.notes:
Not sure how much this should reduce temperature? 

Possibly not being effective due to cloud thinning over time.
‘This reduced cooling effect due to cloud thinning needs to be taken into account for models to correctly simulate the role of stratocumulus clouds in the climate system,” said co-author Graham Feingold, a cloud, aerosol and climate researcher with NOAA’s Chemical Sciences Laboratory. “‘The discovery in this paper is that this cloud thinning increases with time, meaning the cooling effect decreases with time. This is something that had not been considered before.”

0.speaker: The Climatologist
0.text: So far we've seen a modest decrease in temperatures.

c5e9eade-8448-4244-a672-eff84ad7d4dc.speaker: The Climatologist
c5e9eade-8448-4244-a672-eff84ad7d4dc.text: I don't know how long it will last though.

outcomes.text: The presence of aerosol particles promotes cloud thinning, reducing the amount of water in the cloud, letting more solar radiation pass through. The temporary cooling has reversed.

0.speaker: The Fanonist

719d08f4-8d02-41a3-9f0f-57bfd936ea9a.description: Uses the natural flow of moving water to generate electricity.
719d08f4-8d02-41a3-9f0f-57bfd936ea9a.name: Hydropower
719d08f4-8d02-41a3-9f0f-57bfd936ea9a.notes:
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421513003856 gives an EROI of >100, so we'll just say 100 which gives us 0.01kWh/kWh.

https://waterfootprint.org/media/downloads/Mekonnen-et-al-2015_1.pdf gives us a massive range for water usage, 300-850,000m3/TJ net energy...we'll say 425,150m3/TJ or 1530.5L/kWh

http://www.ipcc-wg3.de/report/IPCC_SRREN_Ch05.pdf gives a range of 4-14gCO2eq/kWh, so we'll say 9gCO2eq/kWh

For land use, https://www.researchgate.net/publication/350358598_Land-use_intensity_of_electricity_production_and_tomorrow%27s_energy_landscape gives a median of 650ha/TWh/y or 0.0065m2/kWh

Ideas for tempering hydro:

-Ceiling at ~1.9TW
great resource on this (1.9 taken from the technical limitation assessment range of 1.6-2.3TW)
https://dothemath.ucsd.edu/2011/12/how-much-dam-energy-can-we-get/

-Decrease in generation with climate change
Although big floods can virtually shut down hydro plants, they can also increase generation. The research I'm finding is show a pretty minimal effect, maybe 1%/degree C
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0360544214013218

Limit: in kWh, https://www.hydropower.org/status-report
per Drew's suggestion at a limit of 2000 * 1300 MW plants, or 28470TWh/yr or  2.847e13 kWh

This paper suggests a limit of 53 PWh/yr https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0171844

In the end we decided on 16PWh as a limit (1.6e+13 kWh)
http://newmaeweb.ucsd.edu/courses/MAE119/WI_2018/ewExternalFiles/Estimate%20of%20Global%20Hydropower%20Potential%20-%20Zhou%20-RSC%202015.pdf

7239a338-9ad5-448c-90fd-630a80d299e3.name: Greenland Ice-Sheet Collapses, Causes Huge Tsunami

76ee5397-e5ec-440c-8b25-f489f2a6fd8f.description: A global program to reintroduce predators large and small to a variety of ecosystems. This will increase biodiversity and create resilient ecosystems that can sequester more carbon.
76ee5397-e5ec-440c-8b25-f489f2a6fd8f.flavor: 'The net difference in NPP [net primary production] between higher and lower moose densities is equivalent to approximately 42–95% of all of Canada’s total annual CO2 release as fossil-fuel emissions. Part of this management effort could include ensuring that apex predators such as wolves attain natural levels that maintain moose populations below their carrying capacity.' Oswald Schmitz et al. 2016. 'Animating the Carbon Cycle'. Ecosystems 17, p. 349.
76ee5397-e5ec-440c-8b25-f489f2a6fd8f.name: Reintroduce Apex Predators

Also, how does the trigger event work? What if the player has already abolished animal husbandry or if the Leather Underground already exist--what should the event be?

- increase sea level rise (8-12 in across SE US)
- increase risk of droughts and crop failures, lower ag productivity
- big regional temp changes (temp drops in Northern Atlantic) but I don't think we're able to capture that

collapse unlikely this century but significant weakening possible

> For years, the UN’s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has called a shutdown of the Atlantic circulation this century “very unlikely,” defined as a 0 to 10% probability. But as several studies note, the climate models have biases that could overstate the stability of the current, in part because they don’t incorporate increasing meltwater from Greenland ice sheets. 

should become more likely w/ Greenland melting event

90305bf7-fb26-48ff-a42e-b39f938ded27.text: But if you run out of political capital, you will be recalled and your term will end.

97bb2fde-6668-447b-8d52-904f93f11c84.text: If you get stuck, you can tap on most things for more details and reminders.

a5c99298-f70e-4cbd-86d4-3d7b201b70a4.text: ...Anyways, just click the "Add" button there to start making your plan.

0.text: We're seeing elevated rates of respiratory disease in populations across the world.

25449d32-d132-4734-a172-2e99bd24ba99.speaker: The Doctor
25449d32-d132-4734-a172-2e99bd24ba99.text: Surely it must be from the particles used for the solar radiation management program. They've started settling back towards ground level and entering people's lungs.

13f8677a-fdf5-4261-826b-6dc22c92a6b9.text: The question is, is this end of history or its start?

outcomes.text: Fish aquaculture may have sustained seafood production, but it only shifted fishing pressure from large fish to smaller ones. It also incubated new fish pathogens and resulted in outbreaks of invasive species.

7d6752f7-01ae-44fa-8f3f-049d5633aa9a.name: Island Abandoned
7d6752f7-01ae-44fa-8f3f-049d5633aa9a.notes:
Not sure what a good value for the sea level rise is here?

SR: Tuvalu is considered the lowest-lying nation, with a max elevation of ~15'. I think it's reasonable to say that by 5-7 feet it's evacuated.

Sea level rise here is in meters, so that's ~1.5-2.1 meters - FT

Merging with other island event - FT

Seems a good source--assumes Tuvalu will be abandoned by 2070 if sea level rises 10mm a year. Could someone double check this--the source is from 2009, so I suppose there has already been 100mm of sea level rise since then...TV

Dickinson, William R. "Pacific atoll living: How long already and until when." GSA today 19, no. 3 (2009): 4-10.

7df3f73c-d258-4f3c-9370-f6fe72ec7250.notes:
Emissions and temperature from MESSAGE-GLOBIOM - SSP2-Baseline:
https://tntcat.iiasa.ac.at/SspDb/dsd
Assuming linear growth through each decade

Mt CO2/yr
2020: 42262.425
2030: 46727.551
2022 = 42262.425 + (46727.551-42262.425)/10 * 2 = 43155.4502

kt N2O/yr
2020: 9742.624
2030: 10959.872
2022 = 9986.0736

Mt CH4/yr
2020: 345.346
2030: 373.120
2022 = 350.9008

Temperature:
2020: 1.241
2030: 1.483
2022 = 1.2894
Though https://climate.nasa.gov/vital-signs/global-temperature/ has 1.02 for 2020

Ozone depletion:
According to: https://csl.noaa.gov/assessments/ozone/2014/twentyquestions/Q13.pdf
Was about 3% in 2014, and according to https://csl.noaa.gov/assessments/ozone/2018/twentyquestions:
"Since 1997, total ozone has increased in the range of 0.3-1.2% per decade."
and https://csl.noaa.gov/assessments/ozone/2018/downloads/2018OzoneAssessment.pdf
"Outside the polar regions, upper stratospheric ozone has increased by 1–3% per decade since 2000."

Changing starting temp from 1.289C to 1.1 per Troy's suggestion

7f4e7975-5c5b-451e-b46f-471d8e8301bc.name: Potato Blight Destroys Harvest
7f4e7975-5c5b-451e-b46f-471d8e8301bc.notes:
Trying to find a good figure for plant calorie impact:

https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12230-018-09697-1 says "50% of the world's food energy needs are supplied by potatoes, rice, wheat and maize."

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8302968/ says the breakdown b/w for annual consumption for those four are:
potato: 241Mt
maize: 140Mt
rice: 590Mt
wheat: 478Mt
so very quick calc/rough estimate: potatoes are 16.6% of that 50% so ~8% overall. So the original value of 10% seems reasonable. - FT

7fa623e7-264f-42a8-92b5-6e621539cb03.description: Land-based wind energy technologies harness kinetic energy from the wind to generate electricity.
7fa623e7-264f-42a8-92b5-6e621539cb03.name: Terrestrial Wind Power
7fa623e7-264f-42a8-92b5-6e621539cb03.notes:
This % is all wind power--what % is offshore?
Per the book, assume 50W/m2 (per year) or 438kWh/m2 or 0.00228m2/kWh

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421513003856 gives an EROI of 18, so 0.0556kWh/kWh

For water, https://waterfootprint.org/media/downloads/Mekonnen-et-al-2015_1.pdf gives 0.2-12m3/TJ net energy, we'll say 6.1m3/TJ, or 0.022L/kWh

https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy13osti/57131.pdf gives ~10gCO2eq/kWh

For feedstock, like solar we assume that it's all captured through land use (of course would vary according to wind speeds but I believe that land use number encapsulates an average of those)

If I'm reading these right, wind power limit is very high:
https://esd.copernicus.org/articles/2/1/2011/esd-2-1-2011.pdf - says 18-68TW from land, or 157680TWh - 595680TWh annually
https://www.pnas.org/content/106/27/10933 - says 123PWh annually, including offshore

85f26ed9-db90-4ab2-bd36-ad3523f5dde1.description: Coastal wetlands across the globe are given protected status, and historic wetlands are restored.
85f26ed9-db90-4ab2-bd36-ad3523f5dde1.name: Coastal Wetland Protection and Restoration
85f26ed9-db90-4ab2-bd36-ad3523f5dde1.notes:
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-018-0476-5
General reference

> Rather than being an inevitable consequence of global sea-level rise, our findings indicate that large-scale loss of coastal wetlands might be avoidable, if sufficient additional accommodation space can be created through careful nature-based adaptation solutions to coastal management.

8681d780-79aa-4819-8cf6-363257b0fc9d.description: Produced from methane (CH4), split with steam into CO2 – the main culprit for climate change – and H2, hydrogen. Grey hydrogen has increasingly been produced also from coal, with significantly higher CO2 emissions per unit of hydrogen produced.
8681d780-79aa-4819-8cf6-363257b0fc9d.name: Grey Hydrogen
8681d780-79aa-4819-8cf6-363257b0fc9d.notes:
-Changed input to LNG, key difference is CCS for blue hydrogen

Methane and carbon dioxide emissions (averaged b/w with and w/o flue): https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/ese3.956
Land: calculated using fuel requirements and coal efficiency below
Water: pubs.acs.org/doi/full/10.1021/acsenergylett.1c01375
Fuel: sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0360319919300230
Electricity: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0306261920314136?via%3Dihub#s0105
(We'll use the same values for water and kWh to conduct hydrolysis.)
kWh/kg H2: https://hypertextbook.com/facts/2005/MichelleFung.shtml

Elsewhere I'm seeing EROI of 1:4 for grey/blue hydrogen (https://theconversation.com/blue-hydrogen-what-is-it-and-should-it-replace-natural-gas-166053), still not great, but 1:45 just seemed way too high -FT

874248df-119a-4308-be03-5ac179942027.description: Produce electricity by burning coal in a boiler to produce steam. The steam produced, under pressure, flows into a turbine, which spins a generator to create electricity.
874248df-119a-4308-be03-5ac179942027.name: Coal Power Generation
874248df-119a-4308-be03-5ac179942027.notes:
Per Drew's model/the book, which cites Smil, Power Density for these figures:
1,000 W/m2 per year = 8760kWh/m2 = 0.000114m2/kWh

Figures for US electric power sector in 2020
https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=667&t=6
Coal: 1.13 lbs/kWh = 0.000512559 tonnes/kWh = 512.559 g/kWh

For CO2 emissions, this https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy13osti/56487.pdf says about 1,000gCO2eq/kWh. The book has 8.5kg CO2/yr/W which is about 970gCO2/kWh

For CH4 emissions, https://ourworldindata.org/emissions-by-sector#sector-by-sector-where-do-global-greenhouse-gas-emissions-come-from says in 2016 1.9% of 49.4GtCO2eq was due to methane leakages from coal mining, which is 0.9386GtCO2eq or 0.026GtCH4 with a GWP of 36. According to IEA's Key World Energy Statistics 2018 (https://enerji.mmo.org.tr/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/Key_World_energy-statistics-2018.pdf) in 2016 coal made up 28.1% of the world's primary energy supply of 13,647Mtoe (1.6e14kWh), so coal was 4.496e13 kWh, so about 0.57829g CH4/kWh

For EROI https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421513003856 gives a range of 27-80 with a mean of 56.4 over the values provided, so about 0.0177kWh/kWh. Again, splitting half/half between fuel/electricity.

For water, https://waterfootprint.org/media/downloads/Mekonnen-et-al-2015_1.pdf separates lignite from coal; we'll just use coal here. It gives 79-2100 m3/TJ net energy, we'll say ~1090m3/TJ, or 0.00392m3/kWh

953ba1e1-d0da-4929-a597-7572ebc7f1e3.description: Mandate the use of biochar (basically a baked biomass) in agriculture to improve soil health and sequester more carbon.

image.attribution: GIZ/Tim Brunauer, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

953ba1e1-d0da-4929-a597-7572ebc7f1e3.name: Biochar
953ba1e1-d0da-4929-a597-7572ebc7f1e3.notes:
https://drawdown.org/solutions/biochar-production says "2.2–4.4 gigatons of carbon dioxide emissions reductions by 2050" so let's say from 2020 (it doesn't give a start year), that's roughly 0.073-0.147Gt/year.

This gives an actual yearly number: 0.7-1.8Gt/yr or up to 2.6Gt/yr with this improved biochar:
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-019-41953-0

Kleiner, Kurt. "The bright prospect of biochar." Nature Climate Change 1, no. 906 (2009): 72-74.
it's a bit old, but it suggests that 2GT of C would require 1 billion hectares of land, so 10% of inhabitable area

SR: I multiplied the total drawdown by 15 because we were using a value for one year. Note this is still less than a year's annual emissions. I put a 15 year limit on it because at some point, the soil will become carbon-saturated and that usually takes around 15 years. I imagine there would be some ecological effect to removing decomposing vegetation, so I added an extinction effect and a concern from the ecologist.

https://www.thearcticinstitute.org/permafrost-thaw-warming-world-arctic-institute-permafrost-series-fall-winter-2020/

https://e360.yale.edu/digest/climate-models-underestimate-co2-emissions-from-permafrost-by-14-percent-study-finds
"Scientists estimate there are about 1,500 billion metric tons of carbon locked away in Arctic permafrost, and that 5 to 15 percent of this carbon could be emitted as carbon dioxide by 2100 — enough to increase global temperatures 0.3 to 0.4 degrees Celsius. But these estimates do not include the CO2 that forms when permafrost carbon escapes into Arctic lakes and rivers and is oxidized by ultraviolet and visible light, a process known as photomineralization."

let's say 10% of that 1500Gt so that's 150Gt over ~80 years (from 2020), flatten that to 1.875Gt per year, round to 2

97dbea06-5d32-4e8f-b9f1-f939f61ba9eb.name: Coal
97dbea06-5d32-4e8f-b9f1-f939f61ba9eb.notes:
Just using the values from Coal Power Generation and from here: https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=73&t=11

Those values are given in lbs CO2/million Btu which is 453.592gCO2/293.071kWh.

Values given:
Coal (anthracite)	    228.60

Coal (lignite)	            216.24
Coal (subbituminous)  214.13

In gCO2/kWh:
Coal (anthracite)	    353.81
Coal (bituminous)	    317.90
Coal (lignite)	            334.68
Coal (subbituminous)  331.41

Or an average of 334.45g/kWh

I'm not sure why these are so much lower than the coal-fired electricity values

991816ff-14f8-4751-b2ae-08c6ceef88a5.description: Generate electricity by burning natural gas as fuel.
991816ff-14f8-4751-b2ae-08c6ceef88a5.name: Natural Gas Power Gen
991816ff-14f8-4751-b2ae-08c6ceef88a5.notes:
Per Drew's model/the book, which cites Smil, Power Density for these figures:
4500 W/m2 per year = 39420 kWh/m2
And for emissions: 3.6 kg CO2/W/yr 3.6kg CO2/8.76kWh = 410.9589g CO2/kWh
Which is roughly the figure here: https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=74&t=11 (412.7691g CO2/kWh)

Figures for US electric power sector in 2020
https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=667&t=6
Natural gas: 7.43 ft3/kWh = 210.3942 litres/kWh

For CH4 emissions: https://www.epa.gov/natural-gas-star-program/estimates-methane-emissions-segment-united-states
Which gives (for 2019):
- 12MMTCO2eq to gas processing
- 37MMTCO2eq to gas transmission and storage
- 14MMTCO2eq to gas distribution
- 94.56MMTCO2eq to gas production
For a total of: 157.56MMTCO2eq = 4.377e12 gCH4 using CH4 GWP of 36
For 2020, US natural gas energy production was 1,617 billion kWh (https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=427&t=3) which gives 2.7g CH4/kWh

https://ourworldindata.org/emissions-by-sector#sector-by-sector-where-do-global-greenhouse-gas-emissions-come-from
This also attributes 3.9% of 2016 emissions (49.4GtCO2eq) to fugitive methane emissions from gas and oil production.

For EROI this https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421513003856 gives a range of 20-67, with a mean of 37.75 over the values provided. That's about 0.0265kWh/kWh, which I'll just split evenly b/w fuel and electricity.

For water use this https://waterfootprint.org/media/downloads/Mekonnen-et-al-2015_1.pdf gives a range of 76-1240m3/TJ net energy. That's a huge range but we'll just say 658m3/TJ or 2.3688L/kWh

great study:
Churkina, Galina, Alan Organschi, Christopher PO Reyer, Andrew Ruff, Kira Vinke, Zhu Liu, Barbara K. Reck, T. E. Graedel, and Hans Joachim Schellnhuber. "Buildings as a global carbon sink." Nature Sustainability 3, no. 4 (2020): 269-276.

Churkina basically has four scenarios, including one with 90% of buildings made of wood rather than 99.5% steel and concrete. Significant co2 sequestration (2-20 Gt C) but needs about 40% of current wood production.

Think of it as an artificial and permanent volcanic eruption. The consequences, however, are not fully understood.
abff294f-8058-495c-995c-f86a93ee2d8c.flavor: Victor Hugo — 'Nothing is more powerful than an idea whose time has come.'
abff294f-8058-495c-995c-f86a93ee2d8c.name: Solar Radiation Management (SRM)
abff294f-8058-495c-995c-f86a93ee2d8c.notes:
SRM effect in different areas, rainfall: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0140988320301924
"Climate change shifts the countries' distribution along the optimal temperature curve to the right, so that “cold” countries move closer to climate optimum, while “hot” countries move further away from it. SRM would shift countries to the left and thus have the opposite effect: “cold” countries move farther away from the climate optimum, while “hot” countries move closer to it. Accordingly, countries have different preferences regarding the level of SRM to be deployed."

Degrees of change: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/No-Controls-temperature-changes-C-with-the-deployment-of-SRM_fig1_255556001

SRM proposals have included using gigantic pumps to introduce microbubbles into reservoirs or other bodies of still water, the genetic engineering of crops to make leaves shinier, and the spreading of reflective films on the ocean’s surface or on vulnerable ice flows.

SRM will reduce precipitation: Crook, J. A., L. S. Jackson, S. M. Osprey, and P. M. Forster. "A comparison of temperature and precipitation responses to different Earth radiation management geoengineering schemes." Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres 120, no. 18 (2015): 9352-9373.

No idea how to guess how much percipitation will be reduced in terms of cm/y, but perhaps previous article might be useful. TV

https://www.wsj.com/articles/green-steel-becomes-a-hot-commodity-for-big-auto-makers-11631525401#:~:text=The%20auto%20industry%20accounts%20for,emissions%20related%20to%20energy%20production puts 12% of global steel production for the auto industry

b30c7bef-f826-4a6b-a76d-b8412480bb9e.name: Nuclear Fusion
b30c7bef-f826-4a6b-a76d-b8412480bb9e.notes:
Per: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3263804/
- A fusion power plant would occupy roughly the same land as a fission plant
- No CO2 or other pollution 
- Interestingly, it uses lithium as its main feedstock: "One kilogram of natural lithium yields about 3×10^13 J or equivalent to 9×10^5 l of petrol." So about 8333330 kWh/kg or 0.00012g/kWh

Per land use, we have 0.000119m3/kWh for nuclear fission, so just assume the same esp. if that figure is mostly for feedstock extraction (uranium/lithium)

Jiang, Songyan; Zhang, Ling; Li, Fengying; Hua, Hui; Liu, Xin; Yuan, Zengwei; Wu, Huijun (2020). Environmental impacts of lithium production showing the importance of primary data of upstream process in life-cycle assessment. Journal of Environmental Management, 262(), 110253–. doi:10.1016/j.jenvman.2020.110253  
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301479720301882
LCA of lithium carbonate production (lithium makes up ~18.8% of lithium carbonate by mass), comparing rock-based extraction vs brine-based extraction. Brine-based is way less intense, assuming we use that.
Per 1 kg of lithium carbonate:
- water use: 7.73e2 kg = 7.73e2 L = about 0.0000928L/kWh
- global warming potential: 0.329 kg CO2eq = about 0.0000395 g CO2eq/kWh

For energy use they only have numbers for rock-based lithium:
- Electricity: 3.38kWh/kg = about 0.00000046 kWh/kWh
Natural gas is also used (1.36m3/kg)

TV--I say you have 1-10% chance of it working
--still will be dangerous and produce radioactive waste: https://thebulletin.org/2017/04/fusion-reactors-not-what-theyre-cracked-up-to-be/

b38f3042-0608-4b81-9904-f960774f5746.description: Implement guidelines for all new construction to use little energy thanks to improvements in insulation, clever design, and energy-production, and retrofit existing buildings to follow suit.
b38f3042-0608-4b81-9904-f960774f5746.flavor:
'In 1977, a group of Canadian researchers was contacted by the Saskatchewan provincial government to build a ‘solar home’ suitable to the local climate. Nearly airtight with tripleglazed windows, thick walls, roof insulation and one of the world’s first heat-recovery ventilators, it remained cool in the summer and warm in the winter using virtually no energy. The Passivhaus was born.' Aaron Bastani

seems like 80% reduction of building co2 is possible

Some sources:

Lou, Y., Yang, Y., Ye, Y., Zuo, W., & Wang, J. (2021). The effect of building retrofit measures on CO2 emission reduction–A case study with US medium office buildings. Energy and Buildings, 253, 111514.

b5629cb1-4389-41d3-8868-e4e63e7c56d9.name: Indigenous Sovereignty
b5629cb1-4389-41d3-8868-e4e63e7c56d9.notes:
https://drawdown.org/solutions/indigenous-peoples-forest-tenure#:~:text=Impact%3A,of%20carbon%20dioxide%20emissions%20avoided.

"Impact: Indigenous peoples have secure land tenure on 497 million hectares globally, though they live on and manage much more. If forestland under secure tenure grows by 995–1141million hectares by 2050, reduced deforestation could result in 8.7–12.9 gigatons of carbon dioxide emissions avoided. This solution could bring the total forest area under indigenous management to 1.14 billion hectares, securing an estimated protected stock of 187–215 gigatons of carbon, roughly equivalent to over 687–786 gigatons of carbon dioxide if released into the atmosphere."

This is 12.9 Gt from 2020-2050, so 0.43Gt/yr.

Per Drew's model/the book, which cites Smil, Power Density for these figures:
650 W/m2 per year = 5694kWh/m2 = 0.0001756m2/kWh

For CO2 emissions, the book has 8.8kg CO2/yr/W which is about 1005gCO2/kWh

Figures for US electric power sector in 2020
https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=667&t=6
Petroleum liquids: 0.08 gal/kWh = 0.3636872 litres/kWh

This gives a slightly different value: 0.275L/kWh
https://www.statista.com/statistics/216613/electricity-generated-per-unit-of-fuel-used/

From https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421513003856 we get a mean of about 30EROI for oil, or about 0.03333kWh/kWh, which we'll split between electricity and fuel 50/50.

From https://waterfootprint.org/media/downloads/Mekonnen-et-al-2015_1.pdf we have the following water footprints:
- Conventional oil: 214-1190m3/TJ net energy
- Unconventional oil (oil sand): 419-1340m3/TJ net energy
- Unconventional oil (oil shale): 316-1830m3/TJ net energy

These are all roughly in similar ranges, so we'll do 1022m3/TJ overall, or about 3.68L/kWh

https://ourworldindata.org/emissions-by-sector#sector-by-sector-where-do-global-greenhouse-gas-emissions-come-from
This also attributes 3.9% of 2016 emissions (49.4GtCO2eq) to fugitive methane emissions from gas and oil production, so about 1.93GtCO2eq or about 0.0535Gt CH4 using CH4 GWP of 36.

Per https://enerji.mmo.org.tr/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/Key_World_energy-statistics-2018.pdf oil made up 31.9% of total global energy (total is 13,761Mtoe, or 1.6e14kWh), so oil made up 5.104e13 kWh. Natural gas made up 22.1% of energy, so about 3.536e13 kWh. Assuming that these each leak the same amount of CH4, we can assign about 59.07% of these emissions to oil production, giving us 0.0316Gt CH4 or about 0.6191g CH4/kWh.

cd261811-0499-4383-9fe5-b25587a0da43.description: All other industries not specified elsewhere--including the water and electricity usage across most industries.
cd261811-0499-4383-9fe5-b25587a0da43.name: Other Industry
cd261811-0499-4383-9fe5-b25587a0da43.notes:
Catch-all for industries not otherwise specified or for resource/byproducts that weren't disaggregated into specific industries (and for our purposes don't need to be). For example, we don't have water usage for each industry but we do have aggregate industrial water usage.

Because settlement and infrastructure land use is only 1% of total habitable land use (versus 50% for agriculture), see https://ourworldindata.org/land-use, assume land use for these industries is basically negligible.

A note on "low-income-capita" (LIC)--these are the per-capita rates for a person in a low-income country. If the world was just low-income people but had equivalent total of material footprint, the population would be 37 billion. A different LIC scaling rate is calculated for different resources--all industries are scaled based on material footprint, but household water consumption, electricity, fuel, and plant and animal calories have different scaling rates (see `Consts`).

cfaacae5-9977-49cb-968e-1c9fe1a50879.description: Pump water from the ocean onto Antarctica to reduce melting rates.
cfaacae5-9977-49cb-968e-1c9fe1a50879.flavor: We can use wind farms on the Antarctic continent to create enough to pump enough water to mitigate the current three millimeter-per-year rise.
cfaacae5-9977-49cb-968e-1c9fe1a50879.name: Antarctic Pumping
cfaacae5-9977-49cb-968e-1c9fe1a50879.notes:
https://esd.copernicus.org/articles/7/203/2016/esd-7-203-2016.pdf



Was mentioned in KSR's The Ministry for the Future

"The pumping energy required to elevate the potential energy of ocean water to mitigate the
currently observed 3 mm yr−1 will exceed 7 % of the current global primary energy supply"

"Mitigating the currently observed rate
(Cazenave and Dieng, 2014) of ∼ 3 mm yr−1 is considered
in comparison to the mitigation of 1 mm yr−1 and a rate of
10 mm yr−1 within the “likely range” for the end of the cen-
tury under the high-emission scenario RCP8.5 (IPCC, 2013)"

" Solely in terms of throughput, mitigating
sea-level rise of 3 mm yr−1 would require 90 of the largest
pump stations currently under construction in New Orleans,
each assumed to pump ∼ 360 m3 s−1, which corresponds
to ∼ 11 × 109 m3 yr−1 (Alyeska Pipeline Service Company,
2013). The height of the ice sheet of about 4000 m means that
it would require a constant power of 1275 GW to elevate the
potential energy of the associated ocean water. This is equiv-
alent to ∼ 7 % of the global primary energy supply of the year
2012 (International Energy Agency, 2014). The power re-
quired for the actual pumping may even be higher and reach
2300 GW under optimistic assumptions (see Sect. S1 in the
Supplement)"

"The Antarctic continent is
windy enough to support such pumping using wind energy,
with around 16.7 TW available in a 200 km wide band along
the coast of East Antarctica (Archer and Jacobson, 2005)
(see Sect. S2 in the Supplement). Around 8 % of that energy
would need to be extracted to compensate for the potential
energy increase of the pumped water alone, which is equiv-
alent to 850 000 wind-energy plants of 1.5 MW, running on
full capacity"
https://esd.copernicus.org/articles/7/203/2016/esd-7-203-2016.pdf

From https://www.bp.com/en/global/corporate/energy-economics/statistical-review-of-world-energy/primary-energy.html
global primary energy supply ~600EJ, or ~1.67e14kWh. So 7% of that is ~1.169e13kWh

d76d6cd6-e8ab-4bbf-905b-d292f77e70a0.name: Land Expansion
d76d6cd6-e8ab-4bbf-905b-d292f77e70a0.notes:
Artificially expanding land mass by dredging rivers?

https://dusp.mit.edu/sites/dusp.mit.edu/files/attachments/event/BrenDAmour.pdf
"Urban expansion often occurs on croplands. However, there is little
scientific understanding of how global patterns of future urban
expansion will affect the world’s cultivated areas. Here, we combine
spatially explicit projections of urban expansion with datasets on
global croplands and crop yields. Our results show that urban expansion will result in a 1.8–2.4% loss of global croplands by 2030,
with substantial regional disparities. About 80% of global cropland
loss from urban expansion will take place in Asia and Africa. In both
Asia and Africa, much of the cropland that will be lost is more than
twice as productive as national averages. Asia will experience the
highest absolute loss in cropland, whereas African countries will
experience the highest percentage loss of cropland. Globally, the
croplands that are likely to be lost were responsible for 3–4% of
worldwide crop production in 2000. Urban expansion is expected to
take place on cropland that is 1.77 times more productive than the
global average. The loss of cropland is likely to be accompanied by
other sustainability risks and threatens livelihoods, with diverging
characteristics for different megaurban regions. Governance of urban area expansion thus emerges as a key area for securing livelihoods in the agrarian economies of the Global South."

d7b5da59-37cd-484a-926a-468bb60962f2.name: Rising Taxes
d7b5da59-37cd-484a-926a-468bb60962f2.notes:
Grand Rapids, Michigan had problems with flooding and aging stormwater infrastructure. In 2014, the residents rejected a 13.3 percent income tax cut in order to implement green infrastructure measures that absorb runoff and reduce flooding on streets.

In 2018, Norfolk, VA, which is surrounded by water and vulnerable to sea level rise, approved a $0.10 increase to the real estate tax rate, which will go towards citywide resiliency plans to address flooding. And in the wake of California’s recent wildfires, Marin County is proposing a $0.10 per square foot parcel tax on property owners across the county to fund wildfire prevention.

e467303f-aa32-4e07-ad74-fdffb25f8a04.text: But most of the carbon is found in the permafrost, an underground layer of ice, rock, sand, and soil that is below freezing. The permafrost layer represents the largest carbon sink in the world.

d86ac750-3a91-497a-b3be-d7177f01fe51.name: Boreal Forest Shift
d86ac750-3a91-497a-b3be-d7177f01fe51.notes:
https://daily.jstor.org/climate-changes-dangerous-effects-on-the-boreal-forest/#:~:text=Of%20all%20the%20biomes%20with,that%20is%20generally%20below%20freezing.

https://newscenter.lbl.gov/2013/05/05/boreal/
Boreal forests are the largest “biome”, or ecosystem, anywhere on the Earth’s land surface and account for 30% of the world’s forests. They are a very important store of carbon. While there is a lot of uncertainty around the precise amount of carbon they hold, estimates suggest it is more than one third of all terrestrial carbon. 

And about a third of the boreal biome is underlain by permafrost.

db80f03e-0681-4b85-84e1-fd28254f415c.notes:
https://theconversation.com/everything-you-need-to-know-about-mini-nuclear-reactors-56647

Small Modular Reactors have an increased running cost – each kilowatt hour (kWh) of electricity from an SMR costs between 15% and 70% more than a kWh of electricity produced in a full-sized nuclear power station. 

Another advantage over full-sized reactors is that most countries are better equipped for smaller power loads than bigger ones – the national electricity grid of some countries cannot handle the huge power load from a full-sized power station – they would simply overload and shut down – so SMRs would be ideal in these circumstances.


Apparently they suck. Even more expensive per unit of energy than big reactors, have many other potential problems

dd4e5692-0cb1-4d16-9c30-68db20794591.description: Gradual replacement of hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) with alternative refrigerants like ammonia, carbon dioxide, propane, and isobutane that have a significantly lower global warming potential.
dd4e5692-0cb1-4d16-9c30-68db20794591.name: Alternative Refrigerants
dd4e5692-0cb1-4d16-9c30-68db20794591.notes:
https://drawdown.org/solutions/alternative-refrigerants/technical-summary#
https://www.epa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/en-gtz-proklima-natural-refrigerants.pdf
"Implications of refrigerant choice
Refrigerant choice is normally a function of several factors, some of which are propertybased and some of which are influenced by market issues.
The property-based factors include:
– Global warming potential
– Ozone depleting potential
– Flammability
– Toxicity
– Chemical reactivity and material compatibility
– Potential efficiency (thermo-physical properties)
The market issues are:
– Refrigerant cost (per kg or per system charge)
– Cost of components
– Access to refrigerant
– Availability of suitable components, oils, service equipment
– Adequate expertise and training "


We aren't modeling HFCs specifically (though hector supports it)

This report suggests that "Reductions of between 210 and 460 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide (CO2) equivalent emissions can be delivered over the next four decades through actions to improve the cooling industry’s energy efficiency together with the transition to climate-friendly refrigerants"
https://www.iea.org/news/climate-friendly-cooling-could-cut-years-of-greenhouse-gas-emissions-and-save-trillions-of-dollars
https://iea.blob.core.windows.net/assets/71c8db7e-1137-41ef-99c3-8f2c8d3a5d86/Cooling_Emissions_and_Policy_Synthesis_Report.pdf

So let's say that's like 8.375GtCO2eq annual emissions reduction
This is using best available technology in 2018; 3/4 of the emissions reduction is from energy efficient improvements, "equivalent to an average 40% efficiency improvement."

HFC-134a is the most common refrigerant with a GWP of 1360
Global AC energy demand in 2016 was 2,000TWh; total of all cooling equipment in 2018 estimated to be 3900TWh

Since we aren't modeling HFCs (as far as I can tell they are relatively insignificant in overall CO2eq emissions) we can just focus on the energy use of cooling, especially if energy efficiency makes up the bulk of those emissions improvements.

We're modeling "buildings" as one sector, so we don't have specifics on cooling energy usage. This is for NYC: https://qsel.columbia.edu/nycenergy/about.html but shows that cooling is a relatively small part of energy use. I imagine it's much higher for warmer climates.

For the US as a whole, https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=1174&t=1
> The residential sector’s electricity use for cooling was about 236 billion kWh in 2020, which was equal to about 16% of total residential sector electricity consumption and 6% of total U.S. electricity consumption.
>
> The commercial sector, which includes commercial and institutional buildings, used about 155 billion kWh for cooling in 2020, which was equal to about 12% of total commercial sector electricity consumption and 4% of total U.S. electricity consumption.

So making the really crude assumption that the US covers a wide enough range of climates that we can take these numbers to be representative of the whole world, let's say 14% of building electricity use in general is from cooling, and assume this research gives us 40% energy use efficiency on cooling, then this is roughly gives us an overall electricity use modifier of 0.96

dfd337f1-526d-450e-8155-b02b45efe52c.description: Blast smoke particles in the air to inhibit hail and thus protect crops. Some farmers swear by it, but others think it doesn't work at all.
dfd337f1-526d-450e-8155-b02b45efe52c.name: Hail Cannons
dfd337f1-526d-450e-8155-b02b45efe52c.notes:
Scientifically unproven. steampunk project that does nothing.

In use across america and latin america, to save from crop damage. some say lead to drought.
aprox 1k a year in fuel to operate.
Employed to prevent or reduce hail’s deadly damage to crops, hail cannons can be traced back to an Italian professor of mineralogy, who in 1880 raised the idea of preventing hailstorm formation by injecting smoke particles into thunderstorms via cannon.

In 1895 and 1896, an Austrian wine grower named M. Albert Stiger conducted backyard experiments, culminating in a muzzleloading mortar pointing upward. The device looked a lot like an oversized, upright megaphone, made of sheet metal mounted on a wooden block.

0.speaker: The Engineer

outcomes.text: Anti-hail farmers swear by this method to prevent hail damage on their crops.

e07bcc6c-cb84-4797-b480-560152091526.description: Seize the Means of Reproduction! Make abortions, contraceptives, and other family planning services universally accessible. This will decrease the rate of population growth and empower women.
e07bcc6c-cb84-4797-b480-560152091526.name: Universal Family Planning
e07bcc6c-cb84-4797-b480-560152091526.notes:
"Each abortion reduces total fertility by less than one birth because it results in a shorter period of gestation and more rapid return of fertility than a full term pregnancy. The net effect is estimated to be 0.4 births averted per abortion in the absence of contraceptive use. Higher rates of contraceptive use lead to larger effects of abortion on fertility since the risk of conception is lower than without contraception." https://bmcpublichealth.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12889-017-4740-7

Not sure if I understood that paper correctly, but based on Fig. 4 it seems like the effect of wider contraceptive availability is estimated to lead to something like a 30-40% in births

TV--headline from book by Michell Murphy

e54d7e47-31fe-4578-8966-841207c8bd97.name: Algae Biofuels
e54d7e47-31fe-4578-8966-841207c8bd97.notes:
https://natsci.msu.edu/news/recent-algae-discovery-gives-clues-to-boost-biofuel-production/
For description: trying out writing the descriptions in a way that gives clues as to why you would want to use them, and a little more info about the process - why it's interesting.


https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/B9780323852692000022

This assessment of one particular kind of algae biofuel: https://openbiotechnologyjournal.com/VOLUME/12/PAGE/270/FULLTEXT/

> (50.59 MJ/kg) associated with low consumption of water (28.38 m3/kg) and low CO2 emissions (9.18 kg CO2-eq/kg)

This is about 14kWh/kg, so:
- water: 2.03 L/kWh
- CO2: 655.7g CO2eq/kWh

The energy inputs required is 27.21MJ per kg, will just assume that's all electricity -> 7.5583333kWh

That paper doesn't have land use, but this one provides a range: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1364032117301612

From <0.01m2/MJ to around 0.14m2/MJ. Most of the studies are closer to 0.02m2/MJ, so say that, or 0.072m2/kWh

these numbers seem extremely high--should try to find another source

looking at this: https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/es900705j
gives similar results, looking at the one with the highest energy yield (105MJ per kg), that one has 14.8kgCO2 emitted per kg so something like 507.5g/kWh

And this one: https://www.osti.gov/servlets/purl/1177612
gives 210gCO2eq/MJ which is about 756g/kWh.

so I guess it really is that high

--TV: seems like it would take a huge amount of fertilizer (we should add this to the costs). dangers of it spreading into the wild. No one seems to think it will work. I suggest a range of 5-15%.
--https://harvardpolitics.com/the-myth-of-algae-biofuels/
--Bošnjaković, Mladen, and Nazaruddin Sinaga. "The perspective of large-scale production of algae biodiesel." Applied Sciences 10, no. 22 (2020): 8181.
---Shirvani, Tara, Xiaoyu Yan, Oliver R. Inderwildi, Peter P. Edwards, and David A. King. "Life cycle energy and greenhouse gas analysis for algae-derived biodiesel." Energy & Environmental Science 4, no. 10 (2011): 3773-3778.--seems like it is worse than diesel for the environment

eaa6fd79-b858-4987-8dd5-f31e59bf37bb.name: Vertical Farming
eaa6fd79-b858-4987-8dd5-f31e59bf37bb.notes:
Lucy -  at this point the facility and conditions required to maintain larger scale vertical farming setups in the US is not significantly more energy efficient. Niel Mattson, professor of horticulture at Cornell University "One of the things that we’ve found is that if we look at like New York City, production in a greenhouse had very similar energy use and carbon footprint to growing in California and shipping 3000 miles. It was ever so slightly higher, but just a few percentage points higher than field production. However, a vertical farm had about twice the energy cost and twice the carbon footprint of growing 3000 miles away."
https://gastropod.com/transcript-dig-for-victory/

TV: for me, it seems that it trades fertilizer and water for electricity. Yet, it can only really apply to salad greens and the like and cannot replace more than 10-20percent of crops at most, and definitely can't be used for animal fodder.


Energy use:

> For example, strawberries grown on a conventional farm in Chile require 0.4524 kiloWatt hours (kWh) of electricity per square metre per year (sq.m/year). Whereas strawberries grown on a vertical farm in Russia require over 3,000% more energy at 1,404 kWh/sq.m/year. To put that in context, a four-room HDB’s average electricity consumption is 3.99 kWh/sq.m/year.
https://www.rsis.edu.sg/rsis-publication/nts/vertical-farms-are-they-sustainable/

Other figures here (per m2): https://ifarm.fi/blog/2020/12/how-much-electricity-does-a-vertical-farm-consume
Romaine lettuce: 65.26 kWh / Month
Rocket: 52.51 kWh / Month
Strawberries: 117.10 kWh / Month (in fact, I think this is the Russian vertical farm referenced above)

A major downside that's not really captured here is that vertical farming has a much more limited range of crops it can produce (most often leafy greens).



Other values from here (Table 3): https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7516583/

    water_use = 1 # L/kg/year
    energy_use = 250 # kWh/kg/year
    co2_emissions = 158 # kg/ton
    land_use = 100 # kg/m2, 80-120kg/m2

15kcal/100g of green lettuce, which gives us 15kcal/100g * 1000g/1kg * 1kg/250kWh = 0.6kcal/1kWh = 1.67kWh/kcal

For "traditional/outdoor" farming they give 0.3kWh/kg/year, which, using the same numbers, gives (15/100)*(1000/0.3) = 500, so 1/500 = 0.002kWh/kcal, which is also substantially higher than what we have for industrial plant calorie agriculture (about 0.0001kWh/kcal, so about 20x higher). We could fudge the number to scale the vertical farming estimate down by 20x, but that wouldn't really change much.

Per Troy's suggestion to limit vertical farming output to 10-20% of current demand, the limit is set at 1026000000000000kcals (15% of starting in-game plant calorie demand).

Further reducing to 684000000000000kcals (10% of starting demand) b/c energy usage is so high that the player instantly loses. I think this will happen even at 5 or 10% of demand though. - FT

ebe16973-2208-4d10-be54-5f4631745ff7.description: Rewild newly arid lands into vibrant ecosystems. Deserts can support a surprising variety of plants and animals if given a chance to recover. More plants might lower the albedo and heat up the atmosphere slightly.
ebe16973-2208-4d10-be54-5f4631745ff7.flavor:
Human activities are at the root of our descent toward chaos. But that means human action can help to solve it.

There is evidence that the Sinai once was green – as recently as 4,500 to 8,000 years ago. Cave paintings found there depict trees and plants. 

What turned the Sinai into a desert was, most likely, human activity. Wherever they settle, humans tend to chop down trees and clear land. This loss of vegetation affects the land’s ability to retain moisture. Grazing animals trample and consume plants when they try to grow back. The soil loses its structure and is washed away

f327aaab-c618-4d62-9552-3a18641c85c9.description: The seaweed Asparagopsis taxiformis reduces methane emissions (i.e., burps) from cows. It will take some work to carry out further research and scale up production to feed billions of cows.
f327aaab-c618-4d62-9552-3a18641c85c9.flavor: 'If we accept the most promising claims of the algae boosters, we’re talking about an 80 percent reduction of methane among only 11 percent of all burps—roughly an 8.8 percent reduction total.' image.attribution: "Cows, beach" by David Basanta is licensed under CC BY 2.0

f327aaab-c618-4d62-9552-3a18641c85c9.name: Low-Methane Cattle Fodder
f327aaab-c618-4d62-9552-3a18641c85c9.notes:
How would I reduce CH4 for industrial livestock? According to this article, it might reduce it by 9%
https://www.wired.com/story/carbon-neutral-cows-algae/

I was just guessing how long it would take to research and scale up seaweed production.

I multiplied the .088 percent reduction by the 60% of animal ag emissions from cattle to get -.0528%. I also added a biodiversity pressure factor from seaweed farming and decreased the time to completion because seaweed grows quickly. -SR

7ca1b5b8-5ade-44ca-83f6-b48203ce8920.text: ...in case the worst should come to pass.

adb359c4-6c32-4d50-9ffa-09eddd968b60.speaker: The Ecologist
adb359c4-6c32-4d50-9ffa-09eddd968b60.text: I'm afraid that most of Earth's species will be lost forever.

b31c9093-5b92-4611-94d3-9082c0997111.speaker: The Ecologist
b31c9093-5b92-4611-94d3-9082c0997111.text: It would have been better if we could have stopped extinctions from happening at all.

fc33e72e-1788-442a-81f0-440a105fa026.speaker: The Ecologist
fc33e72e-1788-442a-81f0-440a105fa026.text: I propose a project to collect and store DNA samples of earth's remaining biodiversity...

f3ec3980-6237-49c8-b3d7-c5444c16a983.name: The Ark Proposal

0.speaker: The Engineer
0.text: Our reliance on hydropower as a major source of energy has meant the construction of several mega-dams across the world's waterways.

462bad35-e2df-4661-b723-e96406913985.speaker: The Ecologist
462bad35-e2df-4661-b723-e96406913985.text: As reservoirs fill, upstream forests are flooded, eliminating their function as carbon sinks.

6808e4a0-a9c7-47ea-873a-87d84e9588ef.speaker: The Ecologist
6808e4a0-a9c7-47ea-873a-87d84e9588ef.text: The dam constructed on the border between Paraguay and Brazil in the 1970s and 1980s, resulted in a 70 percent loss of biodiversity.

94bfd6cf-c0ce-4d36-a090-08a3f622e79e.speaker: The Geoengineer
94bfd6cf-c0ce-4d36-a090-08a3f622e79e.text: I for one am really impressed with our ability to shape natural environments and control water.

a98cee2c-d859-4c37-981d-a99d42446e79.speaker: The Ecologist
a98cee2c-d859-4c37-981d-a99d42446e79.text: I realize your intentions were good, but you just created more problems.

aa142cb2-4739-4af1-9340-dcbbcbf77427.speaker: The Engineer
aa142cb2-4739-4af1-9340-dcbbcbf77427.text: We're able to produce quite a bit of power, but it has displaced millions of people and damaged ecosystems.

d29da569-c172-400f-a20e-795ce06c6618.speaker: The Ecologist
d29da569-c172-400f-a20e-795ce06c6618.text: And they just contributed to climate change!

f8db5d96-8ce6-41e7-984b-14aad3e990e2.speaker: The Ecologist
f8db5d96-8ce6-41e7-984b-14aad3e990e2.text: And as the drowned vegetation decomposes, decaying plants in man-made reservoirs release methane, a powerful greenhouse gas.

fbc71ace-7416-4ac3-acdd-3818017e2141.speaker: The Ecologist
fbc71ace-7416-4ac3-acdd-3818017e2141.text: Aquatic species, particularly fish, are vulnerable to the impacts of dams.

fd76da01-3649-4776-8bb5-eb7385b94f0e.description: Expand desalination capacity to supplement dwindling freshwater supplies in stressed regions.

image.attribution: Desalinization plant at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, via U.S. Navy Seabee Museum,  CC BY 2.0

fd76da01-3649-4776-8bb5-eb7385b94f0e.name: Desalination Plants
fd76da01-3649-4776-8bb5-eb7385b94f0e.notes:
https://waterscarcityatlas.org/desalination-powered-by-renewable-energy/

Current most efficient energy use is 3kWh/m3 (3e9kWh/km3), compared to 0.6kWh/m3 for surface water treatment

> The estimated desalination demand for all sectors is 2.6 billion m3 /day. As of 2015, the total online desalination capacity was 44.3 million m3 /day.

44.3e6 m3/day = 16.17e9 m3/year = or about 16.17km3/year

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41545-019-0039-9
> Global water demand for all uses, presently about 4,600 km3 per year, will increase by 20% to 30% by 2050, up to 5,500 to 6,000 km3 per year. 2. Global water demand for agriculture will increase by 60% by 2025.

Hu, B., Zhang, Y., Li, Y., Teng, Y., & Yue, W. (2020). Can bioenergy carbon capture and storage aggravate global water crisis?. Science of The Total Environment, 714, 136856.
Gives 45,500km3/year global water availability

The units we use in-game is 50km3 = 1Water, so let's say each level adds a multiple of that (5e+13L, about 0.1% of the starting supply) to the annual water supply, that would take 15e10kWh according to the current most efficient energy use (above).

https://sciencing.com/disadvantages-desalination-5961767.html

ff462e0a-aea0-4d87-9106-887eda1a7201.description: Perennial versions of the major cereal crops mean they don't need to be replanted each year, disturbing the soil less and sequestering more in deep roots.
ff462e0a-aea0-4d87-9106-887eda1a7201.name: Perennial Cereals
ff462e0a-aea0-4d87-9106-887eda1a7201.notes:
https://landinstitute.org/our-work/perennial-crops/kernza/


Add to crop rotation:
"Another of the worrying aspects of intensive systems is the reduction in biodiversity associated with the application of pesticides, mainly insecticides and fungicides, and with the extensive cultivation of genetically similar plants."
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0167880921004515

Perennial crops would not need replanting –as the main characteristic– because they regrow after harvest. Consequently, production costs would decrease (e.g., lower seed costs) and field management tasks would be reduced (Zhang et al., 2018a, Zhang et al., 2018b). By not disturbing the soil, perennial crops can favor soil biodiversity (McLaughlin and Mineau, 1995), providing, for example, additional niches for soil beetles (Burmeister, 2021). They allow the development of a more natural soil system and, presumably, with improved soil health, high drought resilience and long-term stability (Burmeister, 2021, Sanford et al., 2021). Additionally, considering the higher aboveground biomass production in perennial crops, the use of by-products such as mulch or husks can be increased (Fig. 2).

outcomes.text: The deeply rooted wheatgrass Kernza (Thinopyrum intermedium) is the first to receive large scale distribution.
